intro: Cacalia serratuloides, commonly known as the narrow-leaved bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the family Campanulaceae and is characterized by its bell-shaped, blue or violet flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and is often found in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and chaparral. Its leaves are narrow and serrated, giving it its specific epithet "serratuloides," which reflects its leaf morphology. Cacalia serratuloides is a perennial herb that thrives in full sun and is adapted to arid environments.
